title: b'TypeError for RegularGridInterpolator with big-endian data'
body:
b'I ran into this `TypeError` with the `RegularGridInterpolator` for some big-endian data:
```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> from scipy import interpolate
>>> 
>>> values = np.ones((10, 20 , 30), dtype='>f4')
>>> points = map(np.arange, values.shape)
>>> xi = [(1, 1, 1)]
>>> interpolator = interpolate.RegularGridInterpolator(points, values)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/interpolate/interpolate.py", line 1495, in __init__
    raise ValueError("fill_value must be either 'None' or "
ValueError: fill_value must be either 'None' or of a type compatible with values
>>> interpolator = interpolate.RegularGridInterpolator(points, values, fill_value=0.)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/interpolate/interpolate.py", line 1495, in __init__
    raise ValueError("fill_value must be either 'None' or "
ValueError: fill_value must be either 'None' or of a type compatible with values
```
I think this is a small bug because the Python float `0.` should be compatible with a dtype of `>f4`, no?

cc @andreas-h @pv '

title: b'BUG: cluster: _vq unable to handle large features'
body: b'`_vq.vq` should initialize `outdists` to INF but `ndarray.fill` seems to treat `NPY_INFINITY` as an int32 and initialize outdists to `2 ^ 31 - 1`, so that the result may be wrong when the features are large. Use `np.inf` to fill `outdists` would be safer.\r\n\r\n`ndarray.fill(np.inf)` will fail with numpy 1.5 (only in Cython, no idea why), but `np.PyArray_FillWithScalar` will not. So use the latter instead.'

title: b'BUG?: minor problem with scipy.signal.lfilter w/initial conditions'
body:
b'I set up a system with no input, but with non-zero initial conditions, and got a zero output for `y`:
```
from scipy import signal
b, a = signal.butter(2, 0.5)
y = signal.lfilter(b, a, [0.] * 100, zi=signal.lfiltic(b, a, [1, 0]))[0]
assert all(yy == 0 for yy in y)
```
Turns out this is due to my initial conditions `[1, 0]` being integers, and `lfiltic` returns `[0, 0]` as the output. This seems potentially dangerous to me, at least in corner cases like this. Would it be worth adding a check that `zi` is of the same type as `x` to prevent this type of user error?'

811, in assert_array_almost_equal

  File "C:\Python34\lib\site-packages\numpy\testing\utils.py", line
644, in assert_array_compare
    raise AssertionError(msg)
AssertionError:
Arrays are not almost equal to 6 decimals

(mismatch 100.0%)
 x: array([ 0.1892781 ,  1.        ,  0.30368426,  0.30368426,  0.06227148,
        0.18297787,  0.30368426])
 y: array([ 1.        ,  0.79697112,  0.51113591,  0.00201155,  0.28611295,
        0.4936433 ,  0.00201155])
```

The failures are for the `slepian` window function, and are due to random variation in the return values from `scipy.linalg.eig`.   This script demonstrates the problem (copied / adapted from `signal/windows.py`):

```
from __future__ import division, print_function, absolute_import

import numpy as np
from scipy import special, linalg

np.set_printoptions(precision=3, suppress=True)

niters = 10

# Get parameters
M = 7
width = 2
sym = True

odd = M % 2
if not sym and not odd:
    M = M + 1

twoF = width / 2.0
alpha = (M - 1) / 2.0
m = np.arange(0, M) - alpha
n = m[:, np.newaxis]
k = m[np.newaxis, :]
AF = twoF * special.sinc(twoF * (n - k))

# Loop over iterations
for i in range(niters):
    [lam, vec] = linalg.eig(AF)
    ind = np.argmax(abs(lam), axis=-1)
    w = np.abs(vec[:, ind])
    print(vec[:, ind])
```

This gives output like this:

```
In [76]: run check_slepian.py
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.163+0.j -0.861+0.j  0.261+0.j -0.261+0.j  0.054+0.j -0.157+0.j
  0.261+0.j]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.163+0.j -0.861+0.j  0.261+0.j -0.261+0.j  0.054+0.j -0.157+0.j
  0.261+0.j]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
[-0.671  0.535  0.343  0.001  0.192 -0.331 -0.001]
```

Notice that `vec` returned from `linalg.eig` has changed from run to run, without change in the input.'

title: b'Inserting a knot in a spline'
body:
b'scipy.interpolate.insert allows for inserting a knot (with an arbitrary multiplicity) in a B-spline between two knots (say u_i and u_{i+1}) without modifying the others knots, as described in "Inserting new knots into B-spline", W. Boehm, Comp.-Aided Design 12(4), pp.199-201, 1980.
I have code that relies on that property and worked well for the past few years (since 2010).

Some change may have been committed that did not respect this non-modification of knots, see attached minimal example where for a simple knot sequence (obtained with splprep) some knot is deleted (6), another one is inserted (5 with multiplicity going from 1 to 2).

Has anybody experienced that already ? A clue on the commit that introduced that ?'

title: b"KroghInterpolator doesn't pass through points"
body:
b"I tried interpolating samples from a monotonic function:
```
x = [0, 234,468,702,936,1170,1404,2340,3744,6084,8424,13104,60000]
offset_cdf = array([-0.95      , -0.86114777, -0.8147762 , -0.64072425, -0.48002351,
       -0.34925329, -0.26503107, -0.13148093, -0.12988833, -0.12979296,
       -0.12973574, -0.08582937,  0.05])

f = KroghInterpolator(x, offset_cdf)
```
The first points are interpolated fine:
```
In [63]: f(x[0]) - offset_cdf[0]
Out[63]: 0.0

In [65]: f(x[5]) - offset_cdf[5]
Out[65]: -3.3306690738754696e-16
```
but the interpolator doesn't pass through the last ones:
```
In [66]: f(x[8]) - offset_cdf[8]
Out[66]: 1399.8986518615748

In [67]: f(x[9]) - offset_cdf[9]
Out[67]: 24411.38732329784

In [68]: f(x[11]) - offset_cdf[11]
Out[68]: -68246.638977765731

In [69]: f(x[12]) - offset_cdf[12]
Out[69]: 25511149.696103323
```
AFAIK interpolators are required to pass through the interpolation points. This also appears in the docs (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.13.0/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.KroghInterpolator.html)."

title: b'Integer returned from integer data in scipy.signal.periodogram and scipy.signal.welch'
body:
b"I find it it surprising that scipy.signal.periodogram and scipy.signal.welch return integers for the power density output (not for the frequency output) for a integer (array) input. This is for the present pip version 0.14.0. Is this a bug or really a feature?

```
import scipy.signal
scipy.signal.periodogram([1, 2, 1, 3, 4, 2])
```
The toolbox `spectrum` returns floats for its `Periodogram` class. 

Line 330 in scipy.signal.spectral has `Pxx = np.empty(outshape, x.dtype)`. It seems to me that this should rather be `dtype('float64')` or at least be parameterized?"

title: b'scipy.sparse.rand leaves empty columns'
body:
b"When generating random sparse matrices with scipy.sparse.rand, the last columns of the matrix are sometimes left empty. This doesn't happen every time, though... See below for example. There, the first matrix seems normal, but in the second matrix the last 8 columns are empty:

>>> from scipy import sparse as ss
>>> A = ss.rand(200,200,0.1,random_state=100)
>>> colsums = A.sum(axis=0)
>>> colsums[0,-10:]
matrix([[ 10.87771191,  11.73719644,  13.56566583,   8.31604151,
          12.95205416,  10.31582362,  10.85361546,  10.27116478,
          14.01154514,   6.58907927]])
>>> A = ss.rand(200,200,0.1,random_state=99)
>>> colsums = A.sum(axis=0)
>>> colsums[0,-10:]
matrix([[  4.67479465,  12.52225446,   0.        ,   0.        ,
           0.        ,   0.        ,   0.        ,   0.        ,
           0.        ,   0.        ]])
"

title: b'SuperLU object not working as expected for complex matrices'
body:
b"Hi, please look at the example given in the documentation [here](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/scipy/sparse/linalg/dsolve/_add_newdocs.py#L33), starting around line 30. The example shows how to reconstruct a sparse matrix from its LU decomposition.

The `splu` function works correctly for complex matrices, so this example from the documentation should also work. But when constructing the original CSC matrix `A`, if you set `dtype=complex`, the reconstruction will produce a matrix of all 0's. 

Here is a working example that illustrates the unexpected behaviour. I compiled SciPy today (from the GitHub source), so I should have the most recent development version.
````
import numpy as np
import scipy.sparse as sp
import scipy.sparse.linalg as linalg

class LU_Factorization:

    def __init__(self, A):
        lu = linalg.splu(A)

        self.L = lu.L
        self.U = lu.U
        n = self.L.shape[0]

        Pr = sp.lil_matrix((n, n))
        Pr[lu.perm_r, np.arange(n)] = 1
        self.Pr = Pr.tocsc()

        Pc = sp.lil_matrix((n, n))
        Pc[np.arange(n), lu.perm_c] = 1
        self.Pc = Pc.tocsc()

    def reconstruct(self):
        return (self.Pr.T * (self.L * self.U) * self.Pc.T).A

A = sp.csc_matrix([[1,2,0,4],[1,0,0,1],[1,0,2,1],[2,2,1,0.]],
    dtype=complex)
my_LU = LU_Factorization(A)
print(my_LU.reconstruct())
````"

title: b'NetCDF reading results in a segfault'
body:
b'I'm seeing a segfault when trying to read a variable out of a NetCDF file.  The code necessary to reproduce this is:

```
$ python -c 'import scipy.io; print scipy.io.netcdf.netcdf_file("MDTraj/testing/reference/mdcrd.nc").variables["coordinates"][:].sum()'
Segmentation fault
```

The `MDTraj/testing/reference/mdcrd.nc` file is available in the MDTraj github repository (see issue rmcgibbo/mdtraj#440).  You can download just the NetCDF file here: https://github.com/rmcgibbo/mdtraj/blob/master/MDTraj/testing/reference/mdcrd.nc (I don't see a way to upload a file here).

This segfaults with the current HEAD here and scipy v0.14, but works fine with scipy 0.13.x.  I've used numpy 1.8.0 in all tests.'

title: b'BUG: signal.convolve takes longer than it needs to'
body:
b"While looking into https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/2651, I noticed that convolve takes longer if the first input is shorter than the second input, even though they are computing the same thing ([convolution is commutative](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution#Algebraic_properties)):

    In [54]: a = rand(2)
    
    In [55]: b = rand(500)
    
    In [56]: timeit convolve(a, b, 'full')
    100 loops, best of 3: 5.47 ms per loop
    
    In [57]: timeit convolve(b, a, 'full')
    10000 loops, best of 3: 67.9 us per loop
    
    In [60]: allclose(convolve(a, b, 'full'), convolve(b, a, 'full'))
    Out[60]: True
    
    In [58]: timeit fftconvolve(a, b, 'full')
    1000 loops, best of 3: 146 us per loop
    
    In [59]: timeit fftconvolve(b, a, 'full')
    10000 loops, best of 3: 147 us per loop

So the algorithm is taking 80 times as long as it needs to, and could be modified to take the same amount of time regardless of input order, maybe by just checking which input is longer and then internally rearranging them so that the shorter one comes last."

title: b'sparse linalg eigs/eigsh is possibly affected by an ARPACK bug'
body: b"The ARPACK bug http://forge.scilab.org/index.php/p/arpack-ng/issues/1315/ should theoretically affect `scipy.sparse.linalg.eigs` and/or `scipy.sparse.linalg.eigsh`.  This possibility and its possible resolutions were discussed in https://github.com/scipy/scipy/pull/3599 although I don't think much effort has been put into the investigation yet, on the scipy end.\r\n"

title: b'scipy.signal.fftconvolve no longer threadsafe'
body: b'It appears that somewhere between scipy 0.11.0 and 0.12.0, something changed which broke scipy.signal.fftconvolve in multithreaded environments.\r\n\r\nWhen I try to perform operations on the same input array in different threads under 0.11.0, all works as expected.  Under 0.12.0 (and 0.13.3), I get garbage out instead.  If I wrap the fftconvolve call in a threading.Lock to serialize it, the problem disappears (but obviously, this removes all potential advantages of multithreading)...'

title: b'lobpcg does not compute smallest eigenvalues'
body:
b"I am having difficulty getting `lobpcg` to compute the smallest eigenvalues:

```python
>>> from numpy import ones, repeat
>>> from numpy.random import normal
>>> from scipy.sparse import spdiags
>>> from scipy.sparse.linalg import eigsh, lobpcg
>>> n = 8
>>> A = repeat([[-1], [-1]], n, axis=1)
>>> A = spdiags(A, [-1, 1], n, n)
>>> D = spdiags(A * ones(n), [0], n, n)
>>> A = A - D
>>> A.todense()
matrix([[ 1., -1.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.],
        [-1.,  2., -1.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.],
        [ 0., -1.,  2., -1.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.],
        [ 0.,  0., -1.,  2., -1.,  0.,  0.,  0.],
        [ 0.,  0.,  0., -1.,  2., -1.,  0.,  0.],
        [ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0., -1.,  2., -1.,  0.],
        [ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0., -1.,  2., -1.],
        [ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0., -1.,  1.]])
>>> X = normal(size=(n, 2))
>>> w, V = lobpcg(A, X, tol=1e-8, maxiter=n, largest=False)
>>> w
array([ 3.41421356+0.j])
>>> V
array([[ 1.        ],
       [ 0.84775907],
       [ 0.5664545 ],
       [ 0.19891237],
       [-0.19891237],
       [-0.5664545 ],
       [-0.84775907],
       [-1.        ]])
>>> w, V = eigsh(A, 2, which='SA', tol=1e-8)
>>> w
array([  8.05968790e-17,   1.52240935e-01])
>>> V
array([[ 0.35355339,  0.49039264],
       [ 0.35355339,  0.41573481],
       [ 0.35355339,  0.27778512],
       [ 0.35355339,  0.09754516],
       [ 0.35355339, -0.09754516],
       [ 0.35355339, -0.27778512],
       [ 0.35355339, -0.41573481],
       [ 0.35355339, -0.49039264]])
```

The matrix `A` is positive semidefinite. `lobpcg` returns only one eigenpair. The returned eigenvalue is the second largest. Even passing the eigenvectors returned by `eigsh` as the initial approximation to `lobpcg` produces the same result."

title: b'optimize: stepsize in fmin_bfgs is "bad"'
body:
b'The stepsize in fmin_bfgs doesn't look robust when the gradient is large, and results in convergence failures.

I tried a few examples with fmin_l_bfgs_b and didn't have any convergence problems.
(aside: I don't have problems with fmin_slsqp on my computer, but a similar example (with NegativeBinomial) fails on TravisCI.)

Here is a simplified example that is similar to the problems I ran into with statsmodels, and it sounds similar to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23023851/restricting-magnitude-of-change-in-guess-in-fmin-bfgs/23089696

before scipy 0.13 (including 0.12 IIRC) there were fewer problems with convergence.
One unit test in statsmodels started to fail in 0.13. In some cases I also had problems in scipy 0.12.
The code that uses bfgs is relatively new, and IIRC I never tried with scipy < 0.12.

```
>>> import scipy
>>> scipy.__version__
'0.13.3'
```

The example is just least squares with an exp function. The actual model in statsmodels has the same error structure but different objective functions.

The seeds below create examples that have different failure patterns. Without setting a seed maybe around half of the cases fail.

```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""optimization problems with exp function and fmin_bfgs

Problems with exp type models like poisson in statsmodels
see also http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23023851/restricting-magnitude-of-change-in-guess-in-fmin-bfgs/23089696

Created on Fri Apr 25 23:07:41 2014
Author: Josef Perktold
"""

import numpy as np
from scipy import optimize


def error(b, y, x):
    print b
    err = y - np.exp(x.dot(b))
    return (err**2).sum()

def grad(b, y, x):
    err = y - np.exp(x.dot(b))
    grad = -2 * ((err * np.exp(x.dot(b)))[:,None] * x).sum(0)
    return grad

seed = np.random.randint(100000)

#seed = 69391  # nans
#seed = 37587  # nans returns start
#seed = 22644  # nans returns start
#seed = 90799  # nans  going large

#seed = 36269  # no nans, bad result
#seed = 43347  # no nans, bad result

#seed = 77360  # good, but warning
#seed = 14334  # good, but warning
#seed = 56978  # good, but warning
#seed = 97011  # good, but warning

print 'seed =', seed
np.random.seed(seed)

nobs = 500
k = 5
sig_e = 1
b_true = np.random.randn(k)
x = np.random.randn(nobs, k)
y_true = np.exp(x.dot(b_true))
y = y_true + sig_e * np.random.randn(nobs)

b0 = np.ones(k)

#to check gradient
from statsmodels.tools import numdiff as nd
#nd.approx_fprime(b0, error, args=(y,x))

res = optimize.fmin_bfgs(error, b0, fprime=grad, args=(y, x))


print '\nb true'
print b_true
print 'result'
print res
print 'bias'
print res - b_true

print '\ngrad fd'
g_fd = nd.approx_fprime(res, error, args=(y,x), centered=True)
print g_fd
print 'grad'
g = grad(res, y, x)
print g
print '\n grad diff'
print g_fd - g
```    '

title: b'Operator overloading with sparse matrices'
body:
b'I'm working on a domain specific language for convex optimization in python (cvxpy). cvxpy uses operator overloading so that "matrix + cvxpy variable" or "matrix*cvxpy variable" return cvxpy objects.

But this is not possible with scipy sparse matrices because they raise a NotImplementedError for arithmetic operations with unrecognized objects instead of returning NotImplemented, which would signal to python to call `__rop__` on the cvxpy object. 

Would it be possible to return NotImplemented instead of raising the error? Or is there some way to make operator overloading work with sparse matrices that I'm not seeing?'

title: b'BUG: tools: Unmerged pull requests included in the list generated by gh_lists.py'
body: b"The list of closed pull requests in the release notes is generated by the script `gh_lists.py` in `scipy/tools`.  Currently that script doesn't check if a closed pull request was merged or not.  It should check the `merged` field of the pull request (available in the github API), and skip those where `merged` is false."

title: b'`scipy.ndimage` positions are float instead of int'
body: b'`scipy.ndimage.minimum_position` deliberately returns indexes as float (https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/scipy/ndimage/measurements.py#L1052). If I use those indexes that are returned as indexes, I now get a `DeprecationWarning: using a non-integer number instead of an integer will result in an error in the future`. Is there a reason why it makes more sense for `scipy.ndimage.minimum_position` to return floats? If not, should this be changed? (I could start a PR)'

title: b'BUG: anomalous values computed by special.ellipkinc'
body:
b'This was reported on stackoverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23084112/coping-with-odd-numerical-artefacts-in-numerical-algorithms/

From my "answer" there:

This looks like a bug in `ellipkinc`.  I get just one floating point value where the function returns `nan`, and four adjacent floating point values where the function returns twice the "correct" value:


    In [91]: phi = 0.9272952180016123

    In [92]: mbad = 0.68359375000000011

    In [93]: m = np.nextafter(mbad, 0)

    In [94]: mvals = []

    In [95]: for j in range(10):
       ....:     mvals.append(m)
       ....:     m = np.nextafter(m, 1)
       ....:     

    In [96]: mvals
    Out[96]: 
    [0.68359375,
     0.68359375000000011,
     0.68359375000000022,
     0.68359375000000033,
     0.68359375000000044,
     0.68359375000000056,
     0.68359375000000067,
     0.68359375000000078,
     0.68359375000000089,
     0.683593750000001]

    In [97]: ellipkinc(phi, mvals)
    Out[97]: 
    array([ 1.02593301,         nan,  2.05186602,  2.05186602,  2.05186602,
            2.05186602,  1.02593301,  1.02593301,  1.02593301,  1.02593301])


scipy version '0.15.0.dev-87df1db''

title: b'BUG: special: erfcinv with small arguments loses precision.'
body:
b"Change the implementation of special.erfcinv from

    ndtri((2-y)/2.0)/sqrt(2)

to

    -ndtri(0.5*y)/sqrt(2)

The subtraction caused a loss of precision for small argments, and
anything less than about 1e-16 returned inf.

The boost test data file erfc_inv_big_data.txt
(in special/tests/data/boost/erfc_inv_big_data_ipp) was split into
two files: erfc_inv_big_data1.txt and erfc_inv_big_data2.txt,
Only erfc_inv_big_data2.txt contains useful test data; tests with
this file are now enabled.

Regenerated boost.npz, and fixed the name of the 'ellipkm1'
data set in the code that runs the boost data tests."

title: b'BUG: stats: stats.levy.cdf with small arguments loses precision.'
body:
b'Change the implementation of stats.levy._cdf from

    def _cdf(self, x):
        return 2*(1-norm._cdf(1/sqrt(x)))

to

    def _cdf(self, x):
        return special.erfc(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))

The old implementation suffers from catastrophic cancellation when
x is small, because then norm._cdf(1/sqrt(x)) is approximately 1.

For example, with the old implementation:


    In [56]: x = np.array([0.05, 0.015, 0.0125, 0.011, 0.01, 0.001])

    In [57]: stats.levy.cdf(x)
    Out[57]: 
    array([  7.74421643e-06,   2.22044605e-16,   0.00000000e+00,
             0.00000000e+00,   0.00000000e+00,   0.00000000e+00])

The new implementation is:

    In [58]: special.erfc(np.sqrt(0.5/x))
    Out[58]: 
    array([  7.74421643e-006,   3.21526273e-016,   3.74409738e-019,
             1.50426951e-021,   1.52397060e-023,   1.79583278e-219])

`levy.ppf` also suffered from loss of precision with small arguments.   To fix it, the line

        val = _norm_ppf(1 - q / 2.0)

is changed to

        val = -special.ndtri(q/2)
'

title: b'BUG: do not reject unaligned sparse matrix arrays'
body: b'Fixes scipy 0.14.0rc1 test failures on 32 bit Python for Windows reported at https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/3306#issuecomment-39615085'

title: b'Interpolation with a single nan value is very slow for moderately large arrays'
body:
b"We use something like this over at pandas to interpolate nan values.

```
In [1]: x = linspace(-3, 3, 1e7)

In [2]: y = exp(-x ** 2) + randn(x.size) / 10

In [3]: y[10000] = np.nan

In [4]: from scipy.interpolate import UnivariateSpline

In [5]: s = UnivariateSpline(x, y)
```

This takes a very long time to finish, so much so that I have to kill the process. I'm happy to take a look at the bottleneck here, but I didn't want to start on anything if this is a known issue and/or can't be worked around."

body:
b"

PR gh-3292 fixed some import paths for scipy stats distributions

However it didn't add rv_frozen to stats.distributions.
I think it should be added also"

title: b"BUG: Error in sparse.csgraph.shortest_path with method 'auto'"
b'libatlas3-base-dev does not exist'
body: b'In `INSTALL.txt`, `libatlas3-base-dev` is listed as a dependency. However, it does not exist in the Ubuntu repos, as far as I can tell. On the other hand, `libatlas-base-dev` does exist.'

title: b'exponweib.logpdf fails for valid parameters'
body:
b'`exponweib.logpdf` returns a nan when some valid parameters are passed to it. For example:

    In [1]: import scipy.stats.distributions  as sp

    In [2]: alpha = 100

    In [3]: beta =0.1

    In [4]: value = 0.01

    In [5]: sp.exponweib.logpdf(value, 1, alpha, scale=beta)
    /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/scipy-0.14.0.dev_7cefb25-py2.7-macosx-10.9-intel.egg/scipy/stats/_continuous_distns.py:1009: RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in log
      return log(a) + log(c) + (a-1.)*log(1-exc) - x**c + (c-1.0)*log(x)
    /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/scipy-0.14.0.dev_7cefb25-py2.7-macosx-10.9-intel.egg/scipy/stats/_continuous_distns.py:1009: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in multiply
      return log(a) + log(c) + (a-1.)*log(1-exc) - x**c + (c-1.0)*log(x)
    Out[5]: nan

This corresponds to a standard Weibull with shape=alpha and scale=beta, so it should work. It works if you simply take the log of `exponweib.pdf`:

    In [12]: np.log(sp.exponweib.pdf(value, 1, alpha, scale=beta))
    Out[12]: -221.04816892742841

Running scipy 0.14 from master on OS X 10.9.2, Python 2.7.5.'

title: b'minimize attempts to do vector addition when numpy arrays are passed as args'
body:
b'When calling scipy.optimize.minimize with extra arguments to be passed to the objective function and its gradient, the extra argument is *numerically* added to the original. The desired behaviour is that it is added to a list of parameters.

Minimum reproducible code:

```python
import numpy as np

import scipy.optimize as opt

def Y(x, c):
    return np.sum((x-c)**2)

def dY_dx(x, c=None):
    print x
    print x.shape
    return 2*(x-c)

c = np.array([3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9, 2, 6, 5, 3, 5])
xinit = np.random.randn(len(c))

res = opt.minimize(Y, xinit, jac=dY_dx, args=(c), method="BFGS")
```'

title: b'cluster.vq.whiten return nan for all zeros column in observations'
body:
b'When a column (feature) of the observations is always zero, then its standard deviation will be zero and `vq.whiten` will return a nan, which will make the kmeans functions return meaningless results.
```python
In [3]: from scipy.cluster import vq

In [4]: data = np.random.rand(10, 3)

In [5]: data[:, 0] = 0.0

In [6]: vq.whiten(data)
scipy/cluster/vq.py:134: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in true_divide
  return obs / std_dev
Out[6]: 
array([[        nan,  3.22503459,  2.94333012],
       [        nan,  1.77495108,  0.66684013],
       [        nan,  1.00021902,  0.54654024],
       [        nan,  0.12284469,  1.5192485 ],
       [        nan,  1.45337014,  2.1255432 ],
       [        nan,  3.22419602,  1.87212932],
       [        nan,  1.54394392,  3.49327298],
       [        nan,  0.96204335,  1.6044576 ],
       [        nan,  1.96667524,  1.74163543],
       [        nan,  0.33583457,  3.58268093]])

In [7]: vq.kmeans(vq.whiten(data), 3)
Out[7]: (array([[        nan,  1.33603787,  2.51857499]]), 1.0000000000000002e+100)
```'

title: b"Multivariate Normal error message doesn't cover all cases"
body:
b'If you pass a mean vector with dimension N, and a covariance matrix with dimension M x M, M != N, then you receive an error message:

  File "/home/drp/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/stats/_multivariate.py", line 304, in __call__
    return multivariate_normal_frozen(mean, cov)
  File "/home/drp/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/stats/_multivariate.py", line 458, in __init__
    self.dim, self.mean, self.cov = _process_parameters(None, mean, cov)
  File "/home/drp/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/stats/_multivariate.py", line 64, in _process_parameters
    " but cov.ndim = %d" % cov.ndim)
ValueError: Array 'cov' must be at most two-dimensional, but cov.ndim = 2



This error message incorrectly suggests that the error is due to the number of dimensions, rather than the mismatch between the size of the covariance matrix and the mean vector.
'

title: b'MAINT: use custom templating instead of fused types in _csparsetools'
body:
b"Cython (as of 0.20.1) fused types have issues: (i) unnecessary code generation, (ii) bugs in type dispatch.
The issues seem to crop up if a function signature has two fused-types arrays of the same fused type.

Since we can't postpone 0.14.0 to wait for Cython fixes, this PR converts `_csparsetools` (where the issues appear) to use custom templating rather than fused types dispatch.

Fixes gh-3461

Cython discussions:
http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.python.cython.devel/15250
http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.python.cython.devel/15245"

title: b'FIX: restore np.abs ufunc support for scipy.sparse'
body:
b'`np.abs(csr_matrix(-np.ones(3)))` use to work in numpy < 1.9. With numpy and scipy master it triggers:

    TypeError: __numpy_ufunc__ not implemented for this type.

This PR should restore the support for the `np.abs` function on scipy sparse matrices by mapping it to the builtin `__abs__` ufunc.'

title: b'BUG: sparse: fix backward compatibility issues in scipy.sparse vs 64-bit indices'
body:
b"This PR fixes two backward compat issues regarding 64-bit indices in scipy.sparse:

- `csr_matrix.__getitem__` inherited the integer type from the fancy index array. Fixed by casting to int32 when possible.
- scikit-learn, and presumably other libraries, implicitly assume that 64-bit indices passed to sparse matrix constructors are cast to 32-bit indices. Address this by casting int64 to int32 in CSR/CSC/BSR constructor, if the contents of the array can be represented in 32-bit.
- Added a test checking that 64-bit indices don't pop up in the base test suite

Fixes gh-3465 --- scikit-learn test suite passes for me after these changes.

Needs backport (and possibly 0.14.0b2 is also needed)."

title: b'```scipy.sparse.csgraph.shortest_path``` does not work on ```scipy.sparse.csr_matrix``` or ```lil_matrix```'
body:
b'When called on ```scipy.sparse.csr_matrix``` or ```scipy.sparse.lil_matrix```, ```scipy.sparse.csgraph.shortest_path``` emits the following error:

 ```File "_shortest_path.pyx", line 134, in scipy.sparse.csgraph._shortest_path.shortest_path (scipy/sparse/csgraph/_shortest_path.c:2172)
  File "/.../python2.7/site-packages/scipy/sparse/base.py", line 183, in __bool__
    raise ValueError("The truth value of an array with more than one "
ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all().```'

title: b'BUG: New 64-bit sparse matrices are not backwards compatible'
body:
b'64-bit Linux, SciPy 0.14.0b1 in a virtualenv,

    pip install scikit-learn==0.14
    wget http://scikit-learn.org/stable/_downloads/document_clustering.py
    python document_clustering.py

crashes with

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "document_clustering.py", line 152, in <module>
    X = vectorizer.fit_transform(dataset.data)
  File "/tmp/v/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sklearn/feature_extraction/text.py", line 1223, in fit_transform
    return self._tfidf.transform(X, copy=False)
  File "/tmp/v/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sklearn/feature_extraction/text.py", line 995, in transform
    X = normalize(X, norm=self.norm, copy=False)
  File "/tmp/v/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sklearn/preprocessing/data.py", line 445, in normalize
    inplace_csr_row_normalize_l2(X)
  File "sparsefuncs.pyx", line 117, in sklearn.utils.sparsefuncs.inplace_csr_row_normalize_l2 (sklearn/utils/sparsefuncs.c:2328)
ValueError: Buffer dtype mismatch, expected 'int' but got 'long'
```

With some print statements, I found out that the `dtype` of the `indices` of the term-document matrix changes from `int` to `long`.

**THIS BREAKS ALL OUR CODE**. scikit-learn has many Cython modules that handle sparse matrices, doing things like scaling/normalizing/distance computations etc., that are not easily or efficiently done using `scipy.sparse` functionality alone, as well as learning algorithms (SGD, *k*-means) that rely on the CSR representation to support large datasets and do their own dot products.'

b"The version of clang shipped with OS X 10.9 now errors out when passed the `-mno-fused-madd` flag:

    clang: error: unknown argument: '-mno-fused-madd' [-Wunused-command-line-argument-hard-error-in-future]
    clang: note: this will be a hard error (cannot be downgraded to a warning) in the future

It looks like the issue can be patched around, but the cleaner solution is to remove the flag entirely if clang is detected."

The implementation of this function is just a couple lines that call the function `fractional_matrix_power` in the module `linalg/_matfuncs_inv_ssq.py`. *That* function has a docstring, but that is not the function that is exposed in the public API.  '

title: b'stats.binom, poisson warnings/errors in tests'
body:
b"Tests for binom, bernoulli and poisson generate RuntimeWarnings with numpy 1.8, but not numpy 1.5.1. This was just annoying, but there's a failure now, https://github.com/scipy/scipy/pull/3446
(as a guess --- is there some change in the numpy wheels used by travis-ci?)

On my local machine it still generates RuntimeWarnings:

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import scipy.special as special
>>> import scipy.stats as stats
>>> arg, supp = (1., 0.3,), np.array([0, 1])
>>> q = stats.binom.cdf(supp, *arg) - 1e-8
>>> q
array([ 0.69999999,  0.99999999])
>>> stats.binom.ppf(q, *arg)
/home/br/virtualenvs/py3.3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/scipy/stats/_discrete_distns.py:71: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in greater_equal
  return np.where(temp >= q, vals1, vals)
array([ 0.,  1.])
```

It seems to boil down to (https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/scipy/stats/_discrete_distns.py#L67)

```
>>> vals1 = np.ceil(special.bdtrik(q, *arg)) -1
>>> vals1
array([-1.,  0.])
>>> temp = special.bdtr(vals1, *arg)
>>> temp
array([ nan,  0.7])
>>> temp >= q
__main__:1: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in greater_equal
array([False, False], dtype=bool)
>>>
```"

title: b'Correcting the normalization of chebwin window function'
body:
b'I was trying to work on https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/2221 but noticed that the current normalization for Chebwin window function works correctly only for significant attenuation : 
##### Current :
```
In [3]: chebwin(6, 10)
Out[3]: 
array([ 1.46877571,  0.89172335,  1.        ,  1.        ,  0.89172335,
        1.46877571])

In [4]: chebwin(6, 20)
Out[4]: 
array([ 0.54057352,  0.77676753,  1.        ,  1.        ,  0.77676753,
        0.54057352])
```
In the case of 10dB(low) attenuation, chebwin is not correctly normalized. The tests missed this because they were on 40dB(significant) attenuation.

##### This PR : 
```
In [2]: chebwin(6, 10)
Out[2]: array([ 1.        ,  0.60712017,  0.68083915,  0.68083915,  0.60712017,  1.        ])

In [3]: chebwin(6, 20)
Out[3]: 
array([ 0.54057352,  0.77676753,  1.        ,  1.        ,  0.77676753,
        0.54057352])
```

The results are in tune with Octave and Matlab.

##### Octave : 
```
octave:8> chebwin(6, 10)
ans =

   1.00000
   0.60712
   0.68084
   0.68084
   0.60712
   1.00000

octave:9> chebwin(6, 20)
ans =

   0.54057
   0.77677
   1.00000
   1.00000
   0.77677
   0.54057

```
##### Matlab : 
```
>> chebwin(6, 10)

ans =

    1.0000
    0.6071
    0.6808
    0.6808
    0.6071
    1.0000

>> chebwin(6, 20)

ans =

    0.5406
    0.7768
    1.0000
    1.0000
    0.7768
    0.5406
```
'

title: b'optimize.curve_fit() handles NaN by returning all parameters as 1.0'
body:
b"The presence of NaNs in the xdata or ydata of scipy.optimize.curve_fit(f, xdata, ydata) causes all parameters to be returned at 1.0. This behavior makes it easy to accidentally accept a useless fit. Optimal behavior would be to ignore any point with an x or y value which is a NaN and warn the user.

Ideally, handling of NaNs would be consistent between all curve fitting functions in SciPy. scipy.stats.linregress() returns every parameter as a NaN if there are any NaNs in the data. I'm not familiar with the behavior of numpy.polyfit()
numpy.polynomial.polynomial.polyfit(), or numpy.polynomial.polynomial.Polynomial.fit(), or any other curve fitting methods around.

Here is a MWE that demonstrates the bug by performing (and graphing) a linear and exponential regression using scipy.optimize.curve_fit().

```python
import numpy as np
from scipy.optimize import curve_fit
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
from scipy.stats import linregress

x = np.linspace(0, 4, 50)
for i in [10, 20, 30, 35]:
	x[i] = 'nan'

# perform a linear regression with curve fit
def lin(x, a0, a1):
	return a1*x + a0

y_lin = lin(x, 2.0, 1.0) + 0.2*np.random.normal(size=len(x))
for i in [5, 25, 29, 36]:
	y_lin[i] = 'nan'

popt, pcov = curve_fit(lin, x, y_lin)
a0, a1 = popt[0], popt[1]
y_lin_mod = lin(x, a0, a1)

print('a0\t%s\na1\t%s'%(a0,a1))
plt.plot(x, y_lin_mod, 'r', x, y_lin, 'or')


# perform a exponential regression with curve fit
def exp(x, a, b, c):
	return a * np.exp(-b*x) + c

y_exp = exp(x, 2.5, 1.3, 0.5) + 0.2*np.random.normal(size=len(x))
for i in [5, 25, 29, 36]:
	y_exp[i] = 'nan'

popt, pcov = curve_fit(exp, x, y_exp)
a, b, c = popt[0], popt[1], popt[2]
y_exp_mod = exp(x, popt[0], popt[1], popt[2])

print('a\t%s\nb\t%s\nc\t%s'%(a,b,c))
plt.plot(x, y_exp_mod, 'r', x, y_exp, 'or')


plt.show()
```"

title: b'hierarchy.linkage raises an ugly exception for a compressed 2x2 distance matrix'
body:
b'```
>>> scipy.cluster.hierarchy.linkage([1], method='single', metric='cityblock')
Traceback (most recent call last):
/scipy/cluster/hierarchy.py", line 655, in linkage
    return Z
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'Z' referenced before assignment
```

A reason is that the conversion-to-double of a 1d array with 1 element is returning something other than a 1d numpy array.
```
>>> scipy.cluster.hierarchy._convert_to_double(np.asarray([1], order='c'))
1.0
```

Another reason is that the if/elif is assumed to cover all cases.
'

title: b'minor errors in documentation of scipy Bessel Function'
body:
b'see  http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/special.html

 in the Bessel Functions section.

1. the description of jn() and jv() are identical, however jn() should be "integer order n" while jv() should be "real order v".  (c.f. the entries for yn() and yv() )

2.  in the Bessel Functions section, note that the arguments in the function list (typically x1, x2) do not match the arguments in the description (typically n(or v), z)

3. the optional "out" parameter is not described'

title: b'BUG: linalg.hessenberg broken (wrong results)'
body:
b"The function `scipy.linalg.hessenberg` computes wrong factorizations. Minimal example:
```python
import numpy
from scipy.linalg import hessenberg

A = numpy.eye(3)
A[-1,0] = 2
H, Q = hessenberg(A, calc_q=True)
print(A - Q.dot(H.dot(Q.T)))
```
yields
```
[[ 0. -2.  0.]
 [ 0.  0.  0.]
 [ 2.  0.  0.]]
```
but should be zero. I observed the bug in 0.12.0 and it's still in current master."

title: b'splu does not work for non-vector inputs'
body:
b'splu does not actually work when called with a non-vector rhs:
```
import numpy as np
from scipy.sparse.linalg import splu
A = np.random.rand(2,2)
b = np.random.rand(2,2)
x2 = splu(A).solve(b)
x1 = np.linalg.solve(A, b)
print(abs(x1 - x2).max())
# -> 2.2361768860074456
```
works for vectors:
```
x2 = np.array([splu(A).solve(b[:,j]) for j in range(2)]).T
print(abs(x1 - x2).max())
# -> 0
```
Raises an error for some rhs shapes:
```
b = np.random.rand(2,1)
x2 = splu(A).solve(b)
# -> SystemError
```'

title: b'beta distribution rvs for small shape parameters returns nan'
body:
b'This is the same issue as https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/2056

scipy beta.rvs uses numpy

in scipy we could work around the problem by using generic function using ppf for random number generation

This seems to work:

```
>>> stats.beta._size = 1000
>>> x = stats.distributions.rv_continuous._rvs(stats.beta, alpha, beta)
>>> np.isnan(x).sum()
0
>>> (x > 1-1e-10).sum()
161
>>> (x < 1e-10).sum()
839
```

```
>>> alpha, beta
(7.1e-06, 4.22e-05)
>>> alpha / (alpha + beta) * 1000
144.01622718052738
>>> beta / (alpha + beta) * 1000
855.9837728194726
```'

title: b'scipy.stats.scoreatpercentile backward-incompatible change not in release notes'
body:
b'Hi - I was just bitten by a difference between scipy 0.11 and 0.13 in the behaviour of `scipy.stats.scoreatpercentile`. It seems to be due to 0.12 adding an "axis" argument to the function, which is great but leads to this change in behaviour:

         import numpy as np
         from scipy.stats import scoreatpercentile
         scoreatpercentile(np.eye(5), 50)

On my laptop with scipy 11.0 (and numpy 1.7.1) the answer is:

         array([ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.])

On our lab machine with scipy 13.3 (and numpy 1.7.0) the answer is:

         0.0

I don't know the scipy development process but I believe this change should be in the release notes somewhere, though it isn't - I would suggest it should be in the [0.12 backward-incompatible changes](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/release.0.12.0.html#backwards-incompatible-changes). Does the development team update release notes for this kind of omission?'

title: b'MEMORY LEAK: fmin_tnc'
body: b'In `scipy.optimize.fmin_tnc` I observed a quite troublesome memory leak. See https://gist.github.com/rphlypo/5a412dd290845ebd474d for a minimal illustrative example.'

title: b'MAINT: fix a backwards incompatible change to stats.distributions.__all__'
body: b'See https://github.com/pymc-devs/pymc/issues/454.\r\n'

title: b'TST: remove insecure mktemp use in tests'
body: b'mktemp only returns a filename, a malicous user could replace it before\r\nit gets used.'

title: b'logm fails for singular matrix'
body:
b"scipy.linalg.logm fails to compute the logarithm of the following (non-diagonalizable) matrix:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/5453551/scipy-logm-fail.mat

**EDIT**: it's also singular, not only non-diagonalizable

```
from scipy import io, linalg
d = io.loadmat('scipy-logm-fail.mat')
lnA, errest = linalg.logm(d['A'])

# not diagonalizable:
w, v = linalg.eig(d['A'])
s = linalg.svdvals(v)
print(s.min()/s.max())
# -> 3.0988115615e-17
```
Matlab can do it, so probably Higham has an algorithm that works here.
Fails for Scipy version 0.13.2 (also 0.12.0 fails, so it's not a regression).

The current version of logm can do simpler non-diag cases, e.g. `[[1, 1], [0, 1]]`, however."

title: b'BUG: sparse: fix bugs in dia_matrix.setdiag'
body:
b"Some bugs in dia_matrix.setdiag slipped through. This PR fixes:

- hide details of the internal dia_matrix data representation in
  setdiag(), so that setdiag() behavior is same for all spmatrix types

- fix bugs in resizing self.data, which doesn't always have
  self.shape[1]==N

- add scalar broadcasting behavior to setdiag() for all matrix types

- add comprehensive tests

(Milestone added --- we don't want to have setdiag with known bugs there...)"

title: b'FIX comparison operators for non-canonical CSR/C sparse matrices'
body: b'Fixes #3268, ensures tests are run, and refactors the implementation.'

title: b'CSR matrix comparison operators broken with duplicate entries'
body:
b"```
>>> M = sp.csr_matrix((np.array([-2, 4]), np.array([0, 0]), np.array([0, 2])))
>>> M.A
array([[2]])
>>> (M > 1).A
array([[False]], dtype=bool)
```

I haven't analysed where the failure occurs, but there is apparently no test for this case at present, as `TestCSRNonCanonical.test_gt` passes."

title: b'UserWarning: indices array has non-integer dtype (uint64)'
body:
b'I'd guess, that unsigned types are integers to ;-)

    ...\scipy-0.13.2.win-amd64-py2.7.egg\scipy\sparse\compressed.py:119: UserWarning: indptr array has non-integer dtype (uint64)
    ...\scipy-0.13.2.win-amd64-py2.7.egg\scipy\sparse\compressed.py:122: UserWarning: indices array has non-integer dtype (uint64)

Obviously I am generating a sparse matrix using 'indptr' and 'indices' of dtype 'uint64'. It is just a warning, but nevertheless it bothers me.

...\scipy-0.13.2.win-amd64-py2.7.egg\scipy\sparse\compressed.py
Line 116-122:

        # index arrays should have integer data types
        if self.indptr.dtype.kind != 'i':
            warn("indptr array has non-integer dtype (%s)"
                    % self.indptr.dtype.name)
        if self.indices.dtype.kind != 'i':
            warn("indices array has non-integer dtype (%s)"
                    % self.indices.dtype.name)

It would be more logical to issue a warning when those are signed types, because indices can't be negative. At least 'u' should be added to that validation.'

title: b'FIX support axis=-1 and -2 for sparse reduce methods'
body: b'Fixes #3249'

title: b"Sparse matrix min/max/etc don't support axis=-1"
body: b"Some of the min/max in sparse don't support `axis=-1` and `axis=-2` as they should.\r\nThere may be also other routines taking axis argument that have this issue."

title: b'BUG/ENH: stats: make frozen distributions hold separate instances'
body:
b'This PR fixes two bugs related to frozen distributions with parameter-dependent support.

Previously, rv_frozen instances held a reference to a global distribution instance. 
For some distributions, support is parameter-dependent, and thus some spooky action on a distance:

```
>>> import scipy.stats as stats
>>> rv = stats.genpareto(c=0.1)
>>> rv.dist.a, rv.dist.b
(0.0, inf)                            # correct
>>> 
>>> stats.genpareto.pdf(0, -0.1)       #  _argcheck sets  self.b
1.0
>>> rv.dist.a, rv.dist.b
(0.0, array(10.0))                 # oops
>>> 
```

A separate bug is that freezing did not call _argcheck, so that self.dist.a and self.dist.b were always the defaults:

```
>>> rv = stats.genpareto(c=-0.1)
>>> rv.dist.a, rv.dist.b 
(0.0, inf)                             #: should be (0, 10)
>>> 
```'

The message is of the type: "ascent direction in projection gd = "

Thanks,

Dave

title: b'build problems with the mingw-w64 toolchain'
body:
b'
(1) mingw-w64 - 64 bit: ensure correct pointer definition on the 64bit platform:

scipy\spatial\qhull\src\mem.h

#if _MSC_VER  && defined(_WIN64)

should be changed to:

#if _MSC_VER || defined(__MINGW64__) && defined(_WIN64)



(2) mingw-w64 - 32bit & 64 bit: too many open files

compile options: '-D__STDC_FORMAT_MACROS=1 -D__MSVCRT_VERSION__=0x0900 -ID:\devel\py276\lib\site-packages\numpy\core\include -ID:\devel\py276\include -ID:\devel\py276\PC -c'
g++ -DMS_WIN64 -O2 -Wall -D__STDC_FORMAT_MACROS=1 -D__MSVCRT_VERSION__=0x0900 -ID:\devel\py276\lib\site-packages\numpy\core\include -ID:\devel\py276\include -ID:\devel\py276\PC -c scipy\sparse\sparsetools\coo_wrap.cxx -o build\temp.win-amd64-2.7\Release\scipy\sparse\sparsetools\coo_wrap.o

g++.exe: error: d:/devel/mingw64static/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32/4.8.2/specs: Too many open files
error: Command "g++ -shared -Wl,-gc-sections -Wl,-s build\temp.win-amd64-2.7\Release\scipy\sparse\sparsetools\coo_wrap.o -LD:\devel\py276\libs -LD:\devel\py276\PCbuild\amd64 -Lbuild\temp.win-amd64-2.7 -lpython27 -lmsvcr90 -o build\lib.win-amd64-2.7\scipy\sparse\sparsetools\_coo.pyd" failed with exit status 1

title: b'Updated the buttord function to be consistent with the other filter'
body: b'design methods and optimize the order and natural frequencies such that\r\nthe passband is just met while maximizing the stopband (or vice versa\r\nfor stopband filter).'

title: b"BUG/ENH: special: fix numerical issues in 'boxcox', and add 'boxcox1p'."
b'ZeroDivisionError in broyden1 when initial guess is the right answer.'
body:
b'I'm getting a ZeroDivisionError when I use `scipy.optimize.broyden1` and the initial guess happens to be the right answer already -- not so uncommon a situation in real life, so I'm kind of surprised that this issue hasn't been reported already.  Anyway, here is a code snippet to reproduce the problem:
```
import scipy.optimize
xsq = [ 1, 4, 9 ]  # Solve x**2 = xsq for x.
xinit = [ 1, 2, 3 ]  # Initial guess.  Also the right answer.
func = lambda x: x**2 - xsq  # The function to pass to broyden1
soln = scipy.optimize.broyden1(func, xinit, x_tol=1.e-6)
print 'soln = ',soln
```
I'm using scipy version 0.13.2 with Mac OS 10.6.8 (using the fink installation of scipy-py27), and I get the following output:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test_broyden.py", line 8, in <module>
    soln = scipy.optimize.broyden1(func, xinit, x_tol=1.e-6)
  File "<string>", line 8, in broyden1
  File "/sw64/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/optimize/nonlin.py", line 284, in nonlin_solve
    jacobian.setup(x.copy(), Fx, func)
  File "/sw64/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/optimize/nonlin.py", line 965, in setup
    GenericBroyden.setup(self, x, F, func)
  File "/sw64/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/optimize/nonlin.py", line 672, in setup
    self.alpha = 0.5*max(norm(x0), 1) / norm(f0)
ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero
```
I think the fix is trivial.  Just check if `norm(f0) == 0`, and set alpha to 1 (or whatever) in that case.  

The workaround until this is fixed is to make sure to set alpha to something reasonable.  Passing `alpha=1` to `broyden1` works just fine in this case.'

title: b'Fix int32 overflows in sparsetools'
body:
b'The sparsetools code has several int32 overflows on 64-bit systems:

- Some of the sparsetools routines index into 2D dense arrays.  The indices into these are not bounded by nnz, and can overflow int32 limits.
- The nnz of BSR is not bounded by the index data type, which only bounds the number of blocks.  The block size may easily overflow int32.

This PR contains some tests that require a lot of memory, so we check the available amount first (doing this on Linux should be enough). Some of the tests are also very slow (~ minutes), so they are enabled only if an environment variable is set.

Fixes gh-3212, gh-2179'

title: b'scipy.weave.inline and Microsoft Visual C++: Generated filenames are too long.'
body:
b'The function inline() from scipy.weave store temporarily the compiled files with a filename consisting mainly of a sha256 hash. However Microsoft Visual C++ supports only filename of less than 258 characters including the extension for compilation. Hence the compilation fail. ( https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/121579-visual-studio/suggestions/2156195-fix-260-character-file-name-length-limitation ).

I can think of two easy solutions to fix the problem:
1) Trunk the hash by changin the line 
catalog.py:95:  return base + sha256(expr).hexdigest()
to: return base + sha256(expr).hexdigest()[:100]

2) Use another hash (md5?sha-1?sha-224?sha-3 224bits?)'

title: b'nct.cdf becomes 1.0 for nc >= 65536'
body:
b'From [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21061921/saturation-of-nct-cdf-for-nc-65536-scipy-stats):

"""
I encounter a problem using the nct.cdf function in scipy.stats!

nct.cdf is the t-Student cumulative distribution function, with shape parameters df (degrees of freedom), nc (non central parameter).

Curiously enough, this function works well for nc<= 65535

YET FOR nc>=65536

You will notice that for any x, and for any nc>=65536:
nct.cdf(x,df,nc)=1.0 which is completely absurd!

For instance:
```
from scipy.stats import nct
nct.cdf(45,9,65536) # gives 1.0 ????? (It should normally be close to 0)
```
"""'

title: b'Suggestion to improve error message in scipy.integrate.odeint'
body:
b"If a call to a function that is given to `scipy.integrate.odeint` fails, then there is a useful error message. However, if, instead of a function, a callable object is passed to `odeint`, then there is an error in generating the error message.
The error message contains `func.func_name`. If I pass in a function, that is really useful. If I pass in a callable object, that fails.
I suggest to improve the error message if `func.func_name` does not exist.
See below for a minimal example.

```
In [117]: def g(y, x):
    return np.ones_like(x) + rfg
   .....: 

In [118]: scipy.integrate.odeint(g,4.,np.arange(3))
Out[118]: 
array([[ 4.],
       [ 4.],
       [ 4.]])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
error                                     Traceback (most recent call last)
error: Error occured while calling the Python function named g

In [119]: class ClassG(object):
    def __call__(self,x):
        return np.ones_like(x) + rfg
   .....:     

In [120]: g = ClassG()

In [121]: scipy.integrate.odeint(g,4.,np.arange(3))
Repeated convergence failures (perhaps bad Jacobian or tolerances).
Run with full_output = 1 to get quantitative information.
Out[121]: 
array([[  4.00000000e+000],
       [  4.00000000e+000],
       [  1.39079245e-309]])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
AttributeError: 'ClassG' object has no attribute 'func_name'

```"

title: b'BUG: integrate: odeint handled the banded jacobian incorrectly.'
body:
b"When `col_deriv` is False, the C wrapper that calls the user's python code that
computes the jacobian matrix uses a macro, MATRIXC2F(jac, data, n, m), to copy
the data into the array that is used by the Fortran solver.  In that macro.
`jac` is the destination, `data` is the source, and `n` and `m` are the number
of rows and columns of the matrix.  The wrapper had the last two arguments
reversed.  In the case of a full jacobian, this did not matter, because the
matrix is square.  In the banded case, the number of rows and columns are not
the same.  This means that the only way to correctly use a banded jacobian was
to put the bands in the columns of the matrix, and use `col_deriv=True` so
MATRIXC2F was not used.  That would result in the data being in the correct
Fortran order, since the Fortran code expects the bands to be in the rows.

This commit fixes the use of MATRIXC2F.  Also, the docstring of odeint is
updated to reflect the correct API:  the bands should be put in the rows
of the matrix, not the columns (unless `col_deriv=True` is used)."

title: b'Make distribution pickle-able '
body:
b"It would be nice if you could pickle all `scipy.stats` distributions. Currently it does not work because python can't pickle instancemethod objects.

This, in my oppinion should work:
```python
In [1]: from scipy.stats import beta
In [2]: dist = beta(1, 1)
In [3]: import pickle
In [4]: pickle.dumps(dist)
```

However, it currently does not.
```
TypeError: can't pickle instancemethod objects
```
Is there any way to change this behavior without breaking backward compatibility?

I'd be willing to put in some work, I just need some advice."

title: b'fmin_slsqp constraint violation with 0 exit code'
body:
b"In the thread of the same name on SciPy-Users last month

   http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.comp.python.scientific.user/34744

a reproducible example was requested; here's one, based on p. 142 of D. M. Greig's *Optimisation* (1980, Longman Mathematical Texts).

```python
def f(x):
    return sum((x - np.array([1., 2., 3., 4.]))**2)

def constraint(x):
    return np.concatenate([np.dot(np.array([[-1, -1, -1, -1],
                                            [-3, -3, -2, -1]]),
                                  x) + np.array([5, 10]),
                           x])

out = fmin_slsqp(f, np.array([0.5, 1., 1.5, 2.]), f_ieqcons=constraint,
                 full_output=True)
print out
print constraint(out[0])
```

Running this with scipy.version.version=0.13.0 (installed via pip) on x86_64 Linux Mint Debian Edition, I get 

```
(array([-0.17391304,  0.82608696,  2.2173913 ,  3.60869565]), 3.5217391304347778, 14, 0, 'Optimization terminated successfully.')
[ -1.47826087e+00  -7.10542736e-15  -1.73913042e-01   8.26086956e-01
   2.21739130e+00   3.60869565e+00]
```

which is wrong (the first three, or at least the first and third, constraints are negative).  The exact solution (Greig) is np.array([0., 2, 5, 8])/3.

Running on another x86_64 LMDE machine with scipy 0.12.0 (installed from APT python-scipy), I do get the correct answer.
"

1. arguments are different
    sem(a, axis=0, ddof=1) for stats
    sem(a, axis=0): for mstats

2. normalization is different
    / sqrt(n-1) in mstats
   / sqrt(n) in stats

title: b'Standard testing of mstats vs. stats results'
body:
b'This pull request has two purposes:

1) providing a framework for improved unittesting of mstats functions by comparing against stats functions
2) provide a variety of bugfixes for bugs I found in mstats, when comparing stats functions against mstats.

top #1:
I implemented a test class which allows unittesting the results between stats and mstats.
This work originated from the following this issue (https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/2318).

What you can do:
a) compare stats and mstats results in a consistent manner
b) print a table which gives you an overview about the routines which have already unittests implemented (use print_stats_mstats_comparison for this)

Results of the unittests indicate that for some routines in mstats there are bugs. I have initially commented these tests in the code, so the tests run properly through.

top #2:
While doing the unittesting, a couple of errors occured, which I could identify as bugs in mstats routines. I tried to fix them.
When doing the bugfixing I had also to add new arguments to a couple of routines. I ensured that the mstats routines remain backward compatible. As a result, the default arguments between mstats and stats routines somehow differ in some cases.


'

title: b'Wrong output of scipy.ndimage.measurements.label()'
body:
b'The documentation of the method scipy.ndimage.measurements.label() states that the output will contain the labeled image and the number of features found. On the top, the description clearly says that a feature is any non-zero value.
This description proves the following output to be wrong:

    import numpy as np
    import scipy.ndimage

    x = np.zeros((5, 5))
    [labels, no_features] = scipy.ndimage.measurements.label(x)

    print(no_features) # prints 1

The former version of scipy (0.12.0) calculates the correct value => 0'

title: b'Inverted check of size in scipy.ndimage.measurements.label()'
body:
b"`scipy.ndimage.measurements.label()` has the following lines:
```
    # Use 32 bits if it's large enough for this image.
    # _ni_label.label()  needs two entries for background and
    # foreground tracking
    need_64bits = input.size < (2**31 - 2)
```
I think that `<` should be replaced with `>=`."

title: b"wavfile doesn't work with 24-bit audio files"
body:
b"When a wav file contains 24-bit audio, wavfile tries to read it via `dtype('<i3')`. However, there is no such native integer type, and it ends up trying to read `dtype('<i4')`, which of course doesn't work as the byte counts don't match.

This should be fixed in `wavfile`.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19780983/scipy-wavfile-music-in-garbage-out

"

title: b'scipy.optimize.curve_fit leads to unexpected behavior when input is a standard python list'
body:
b'Inspired by the Stack Overflow question:

http://stackoverflow.com/q/19713689/249341

A minimal working example of the potential pitfall:

    import numpy as np
    import scipy.optimize

    x = [1,2,3,4]
    y = [2,4,6,8]

    def f(x,a,b): return a*x + b

    print "Expected: ", scipy.optimize.curve_fit(f, np.array(x), y)[0]
    print "Observed: ", scipy.optimize.curve_fit(f, x, y)[0]

Gives:

    Expected:  [  2.00000000e+00  -4.44089210e-16]
    Observed:  [ 1.   2.5]

It's clear what is going on here, when `x` is a standard python list `a*x` makes `a` copies of that list. For someone new to python, and is working primarily with the scipy/numpy stack this is an extremely strange and unexpected behavior (I've watched more than one person struggle with this). 

Suggestions:

1] Is there any reason _not_ to cast python lists into numpy arrays? If not, then automatically cast on input
2] Check the size of 'x', via `len`. If it changes size during optimization, perhaps give a warning?
3] At the very least, update the docs to know that there won't be an upcast?

'

title: b'stats.mode seems suprisingly slow (at least on 1-2 dimensions)'
body:
b"stats.mode seems surprisingly slow, especially since it's very much the same as `find_repeats`. Despite only needing to return the first value and being pretty much the same function, stats.mode is much slower than find_repeats (which appears to be a very thin wrapper around a fortran function), here's some benchmarking:

```python
import numpy as np
import scipy.stats as stats
arr1 = np.random.randint(-1000, 1000, 10000)
%timeit stats.mode(arr1)
%timeit stats.find_repeats(arr1)
```
which yields
```
10 loops, best of 3: 142 ms per loop
1000 loops, best of 3: 832 s per loop
```

The problem is that the implementation is very slow when the number of unique labels is much greater than the number of unique values, because it iterates over every count:

```python
arr1 = np.random.randint(-100, 100, 10000)
ser = pd.Series(arr1)
%timeit stats.mode(arr1)
%timeit stats.find_repeats(arr1)
```
yields
```
100 loops, best of 3: 15.2 ms per loop
1000 loops, best of 3: 681 s per loop
```

And is still twice as slow with 20 uniques vs. 10000 entries:

```
arr1 = np.random.randint(-10, 10, 10000)
%timeit stats.mode(arr1)
%timeit stats.find_repeats(arr1)
```

yielding
```
1000 loops, best of 3: 1.89 ms per loop
1000 loops, best of 3: 508 s per loop
```

And still not great with 2 dimensions:

```python
arr1 = np.random.randint(-100, 100, (500, 100))
%timeit stats.mode(arr1)
%timeit stats.find_repeats(arr1)
# approximate finding repeats on each axis:
%timeit [stats.find_repeats(arr1[i]) for i in range(len(arr1))]
```
which yields:
```
10 loops, best of 3: 50.6 ms per loop
100 loops, best of 3: 3.6 ms per loop
100 loops, best of 3: 4.61 ms per loop
```

At least for 1D, a better implementation would be to take advantage of find_repeats (or reuse its internals) rather than iterating over uniques, e.g. something like this for 1D:

```python
def faster_mode1D(a):
    arr = np.asarray(a) # would be _chk_array
    v, c = stats.find_repeats(arr)
    if len(c) == 0:
        arr.sort() # mimic first value behavior
        return arr[0], 1.
    else:
        pos = c.argmax()
        return v[pos], c[pos]
```

Not sure whether this makes as much sense for multiple dimensions, but maybe it would be worth special-casing 1D ndarrays?  The performance difference is pretty big."

title: b'problem with scipy.spsolve when matrix has dimension 1x1'
body:
b'Hi,
if you solve a problem like the following with scipy:
 spsolve(np.array([[1]]),np.array([[4]]))

you will get an error.

The error happens at line 114 of file linsolve.py:

114   if M != b.shape[0]:
115        raise ValueError("matrix - rhs dimension mismatch (%s - %s)"
116                         % (A.shape, b.shape[0]))

This is because at line 96, the rhs b is transformed through squeeze:
b = b.squeeze()

As a consequence, b.shape is empty.

You may ask why solving 1D problems through spsolve?

The answer is that problem size can be a dynamic variable depending on problem arguments.

Thanks'

title: b'scipy.ndimage.label() broken in scipy 0.13'
body:
b'I am using Python 3.3.2 on 64-bit Arch Linux.

I have a script that skeletonizes an image and then i run:
ndimage.label(skeletonized_image, np.ones((3, 3)))

When using scipy 0.12, label counts about 30 seperate objects which are clearly disconnected.

When using scipy 0.13, I label generates about twice the amount of objects many of which are clearly connected.

i.e.
[0, 0, 0, 0;
 1, 1, 2, 2;
 0, 0, 0, 0]

For now downgrading to scipy 0.12 has solved the problem.'

title: b'Bug in stats.fisher_exact'
body:
b'A problem with stats.fisher_exact was reported on stackoverflow:
    http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19548854/python-scipy-stats-module-valueerror-axis-entry-is-out-of-bounds

The culprit appears to be this line:
    https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/scipy/stats/stats.py#L2633
I assume that `np.max(pexact, pmode)` should be `np.maximum(pexact, pmode)`.  

As it is now, `pmode` is being passed to `np.max()` as its `axis` argument.  Usually `pmode` is less than 1, so the `axis` value is truncated to 0 and an error is not generated.  For the special case reported in the Stack Overflow question, `stats.fisher_exact([[1,2],[9,84419233]])`, `pmode` is 1.00000001738, so an error is raised.




'

title: b'Add `scipy.optimize.Result` to API docs'
body:
b"The return value of `scipy.optimize.minimize` is a `scipy.optimize.Result` object as described here:
http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-dev/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.minimize.html

But `scipy.optimize.Result` is currently missing from the scipy API docs.
I guess all that is needed is to list it in the docstring here?
https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/scipy/optimize/__init__.py
But I wasn't sure where to put it ... a new section at the end?"

title: b'Problems running what seems a perfectly valid example'
body:
b'I'm doing some work in filtering and having a bit of a rough time.  I went looking for some examples and I found this:

http://azitech.wordpress.com/2011/03/15/designing-a-butterworth-low-pass-filter-with-scipy/

It looks to me like a perfectly valid set of examples, and he's even generated some example output.  It looks reasonable.

So I download the code and try running it on my machine.  I see this error:
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/scipy/signal/filter_design.py:288: BadCoefficients: Badly conditioned filter coefficients (numerator): the results may be meaningless
  "results may be meaningless", BadCoefficients)
b=[  1.50249921e-18], a=[   1.           -9.78671066   43.10310124 -112.50164481  192.7084543
 -226.36430741  184.66074807 -103.30140929   37.92528936   -8.25143211
    0.80791132]

And then the graph looks substantially different:
![output](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/104520/1318475/01f08752-32bd-11e3-8336-cacdc0cbac40.png)

The thing that strikes me is that in the filter passbands are HUGELY different.  The example output he shows has a passband gain of 1.  My passband gain is 10^-5 so it's all attenuation.

I found this ticket https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/2140 and it mentioned problems with the "small enough to zero out" number.  I'm running a newer version of scipy which already has the 1e-14 threshold so that doesn't seem to be the problem.

This is really puzzling me.'

title: b'scipy.stats.mstats.winsorize documentation error'
body:
b'I'm using SciPy version 0.10.1 with GIT revision: '772893ff951c61f15a710b3b773ac12e69254fa4'.

In the mstats module, the winsorize function looks to have a bad specification for the upper percentile limit.

The docstring says, "The (limits[0])th lowest values are set to the (limits[0])th percentile, and the (limits[1])th highest values are set to the (limits[1])th percentile."

In this mode of usage, if you wanted to winsorize at the 5% and 95% levels, you would call the function with limits=(0.05, 0.05). But based on the docstring, this makes it sound as if the limits[1]th highest values (so top 5%) will get the score from the (limits[1])th (so 5%) percentile. But actually you get the (1-limits[1])th percentile (the 95% score).

I hit the error because the documentation makes it sound very much like the way to use the function is with limits=(0.05, 0.95) (I would argue this is the most clear way to accept args for winsorization). But if you do this on an array of, for example, 10 elements, you'll see that the output is a constant array.'

title: b'scipy.integrate.quadpack.nquad() incompatible with Python 3.1'
body:
b"SciPy 0.13.0 beta1 introduced `scipy.integrate.quadpack.nquad()` function, which contains 2 calls to `callable()`.
`callable()` is not available in Python 3.1, so it needs to be imported from scipy.lib.six.
This patch fixes 9 errors in test suite with Python 3.1.

```
--- scipy/integrate/quadpack.py
+++ scipy/integrate/quadpack.py
@@ -9,6 +9,8 @@
 import numpy
 from numpy import Inf
 
+from scipy.lib.six import callable
+
 __all__ = ['quad', 'dblquad', 'tplquad', 'nquad', 'quad_explain']
 
 
```"

title: b'test_orthogonal_eval.TestRecurrence issue with MinGW build'
body:
b'With 0.13.x:
    ======================================================================
    ERROR: test_orthogonal_eval.TestRecurrence.test_chebyc
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "C:\Python32\lib\site-packages\nose-1.1.2-py3.2.egg\nose\case.py", line 198, in runTest
        self.test(*self.arg)
      File "C:\Python32\lib\site-packages\scipy\special\tests\test_orthogonal_eval.py", line 214, in test_chebyc
        param_ranges=[], x_range=[-2, 2])
      File "C:\Python32\lib\site-packages\scipy\special\tests\test_orthogonal_eval.py", line 170, in check_poly
        z = np.c_[np.tile(p, (nx,1)), x, func(*(p + (x,)), **kw)]
    TypeError: invalid keyword

And 12 more of the same. The issue seems to be that the ``eval_*`` don't accept a ``sig`` keyword. Maybe related with the f2py wrappers behaving differently for g77?

There were other MinGW issues with these functions (see gh-339) but it doesn't really look related.'

title: b"Some links don't work in `interpolate` reference html docs"
body:
b'This page contains two "see also" sections:
http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-dev/reference/interpolate.html

In the first one `scipy.ndimage.map_coordinates` is not a HTML link.
In the second one some of the HTML links do work, but for these functions they currently don't:
* `scipy.ndimage.map_coordinates`
* `scipy.ndimage.spline_filter`
* `scipy.signal.qspline1d_eval`
'

title: b'Sparse/dense matrix inplace operations fail due to __numpy_ufunc__'
body:
b'With current Scipy master + Numpy master, the following fails:
```
>>> x = np.ones(4)
>>> y = scipy.sparse.csr_matrix(x)
>>> x += y
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: __numpy_ufunc__ not implemented for this type.
```
This used to work via `csr_matrix.__radd__`, but the current behavior in Numpy master is to pass through the exception rather than return NotImplemented, so that `__radd__` is never called.

Two places to fix:

(i) The scipy.spmatrix should support the `out` array argument
(ii) Numpy should be fixed so that `__radd__` gets called even if the `__numpy_ufunc__` mechanism ends up with the conclusion that the operation is not supported.'

title: b"Regression in identity(x).setdiag() -- doesn't work now with diag_matrix"
body:
b'Not sure if you would like to do anything about it but decided to share "user experience"

Here is output of 
```
$> python -c 'import scipy.sparse; print scipy.__version__;s=scipy.sparse.identity(2); print type(s); s.setdiag([1,2]); print s'
```
on different scipy versions
```
0.7.2
<class 'scipy.sparse.csr.csr_matrix'>
  (0, 0)	1.0
  (1, 1)	2.0

0.10.1
<class 'scipy.sparse.csr.csr_matrix'>
  (0, 0)	1.0
  (1, 1)	2.0

$> python -c 'import scipy.sparse; print scipy.__version__;s=scipy.sparse.identity(2); print type(s); s.setdiag([1,2]); print s'
0.12.0
<class 'scipy.sparse.dia.dia_matrix'>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/scipy/sparse/base.py", line 622, in setdiag
    self[i, i + k] = v
TypeError: 'dia_matrix' object does not support item assignment
```

workaround to get consistent with previous behavior is to enforce 'csr' type by providing ```format='csr'``` to identity.'

body:
b'python3.3, scipy 0.13b1 run on i386 debian unstable with numpy 1.7.1.

twelve >i8 tests fail with this error (hurd here but also linux32 bit):

```

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/nose/case.py", line 198, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "/build/buildd-python-scipy_0.13.0~b1-1-hurd-i386-jz8INl/python-scipy-0.13.0~b1/debian/python3-scipy/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/scipy/io/tests/test_wavfile.py", line 70, in _check_roundtrip
    wavfile.write(tmpfile, rate, data)

    fid.seek(4)
ValueError: cannot expose native-only dtype 'q' in non-native byte order '>' via buffer interface

https://buildd.debian.org/status/package.php?p=python-scipy&suite=experimental'

title: b'ndimage.percentile_filter ignores origin argument for multidimensional inputs'
body:
b"The percentile_filter seems to ignore the origin argument when the input is not a vector. Here is a test example that compares the result of a percentile_filter on a vector vs. an Nx1 array. I would expect the results to be identical, but using non-zero origins yields the same result as using zero origins on the Nx1 array.
```
import numpy as np
from scipy.ndimage.filters import percentile_filter
x = np.arange(10).reshape(10,1)
y = x.flatten()
x0 = percentile_filter(x, 0, size=(3,1), origin=(0,0)).flatten()
x1 = percentile_filter(x, 0, size=(3,1), origin=(-1,0)).flatten()
y0 = percentile_filter(y, 0, size=3, origin=0)
y1 = percentile_filter(y, 0, size=3, origin=-1)
print 'Error with origin=0:', np.sum((y0-x0)**2)
print 'Error with origin=-1:', np.sum((y1-x1)**2)
print 'Difference between origin=0 and origin=-1 for array:', np.sum((x1 -x0)**2)
```
Output:
```
Error with origin=0: 0
Error with origin=-1: 8
Difference between origin=0 and origin=-1 for array: 0
```"

title: b'future division introduces floating indices in odrpack.py'
body:
b'in the set_iprint method of the ODR class, the computation of the ip list should use integer division. Since the import of the future division, it leads to floating indices.
''''
/tmp/test.py in optimization(freq, Z, lFapp, lQapp, lZapp, output_snCn, trace, optfun, fmin, fmax)
    516         syst = odr.ODR(data, model, beta0=coefs_0, \
    517             partol=1e-3, sstol=1e-5)
--> 518         syst.set_iprint(init=0, iter=0, iter_step=0, final=0)
    519         # syst.set_job(deriv=2)
    520         # TODO: Problem with the derivatives (not used).

/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/scipy/odr/odrpack.pyc in set_iprint(self, init, so_init, iter, so_iter, iter_step, final, so_final)
   1052                 "no rptfile specified, cannot output to stdout twice")
   1053 
-> 1054         iprint_l = ip2arg[ip[0]] + ip2arg[ip[1]] + ip2arg[ip[3]]
   1055 
   1056         if init is not None:

TypeError: list indices must be integers, not float
'''''

title: b'Trimmed statistics functions have inconsistent API'
body:
b"These functions are:

- tmin
- tmax
- tmean
- tstd
- tvar
- tsem

They should all be made consistent, probably all need keywords ``axis`` and ``ddof``. ``tsem`` should be made consistent with ``sem``. The relation between ``tmean`` and ``trim_mean`` should be clarified.

Those functions are now all tested to some extent after gh-2913. What's left to do there is to test their behavior with masked arrays. Examples should also still be added. 

"

title: b'scipy.stats.chisquare - type required of f_exp is inconsistent with type required of f_obs'
body:
b'chisquare(f_obs = [1,1,1,1,1]) # This is OK

chisquare(f_obs = [1,1,1,1,1], f_exp = [1,1,1,1,1]) # throws f_exp 'list' object has no attribute 'astype'

chisquare(f_obs = [1,1,1,1,1], f_exp = np.array([1,1,1,1,1])) # But this is OK

In docs (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.stats.chisquare.html), f_exp and f_obs both have type "array". Either f_exp should be required to be a numpy array or f_obs should be allowed to be a list.

Thanks!'

title: b'COBYLA successful termination when constraints violated'
body:
b'The `fmin_cobyla` algorithm can terminate without actually satisfying the constraints.
Indeed, it has a `maxcv` return value that reports the constraint violation.

See e.g. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18782092/python-scipy-optimization-issue-fmin-cobyla-one-constraint-is-not-respected http://pastebin.com/gjbeePgt

This is quite surprising behavior, and definitely not adequately documented.
The COBYLA wrappers probably should check the constraint violation, and return with a failed status if it is bigger than some allowed tolerance.'

title: b'The ppf method in stats.distributions does not take array-like parameter input correctly'
body:
b"Probably a known bug as I googled the old issue #1131 __Scipy Stats ppf for Lognormal fails on array-like 'loc' or 'scale'__ 

For example, 
```python
stats.distribution.norm.pdf([0.5, 0.6], [0, 0], [1, 1]) 
``` 
works, but 
```python
stats.distribution.norm.ppf([0.5, 0.6], [0, 0], [1, 1])
``` 
doesn't. The same issue holds for other types of distributions, such as gamma"

title: b'vecentropy.nin  is wrong'
body:
b'(vectorize.nin is always fun)

I think vecentropy.nin in line 1030 is wrong, but I'm surprised it works with 1.7 
(but I only have numpy 1.5 and numpy 1.6 active right now)
should be
`self.vecentropy.nin = self.numargs + 0`
because vecentropy doesn't take an additional argument besides dist args

It looks like vectorize.nin can be too large and it still works (but cannot be too small - in some cases ?)

```
>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy(0.5)
array(-0.6990879746455713)
>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy.nin
2
>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy.nin = 1

array(-0.6990879746455713)

1

>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy(0.5)
array(-0.6990879746455713)
>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy.nin
5

>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy.nin = 0   #too small, still works
>>> stats.rdist.vecentropy(0.5)
array(-0.6990879746455713)
>>> np.__version__
'1.6.1'
```
